[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: load_config()] [Deserialization Attack] Can an attacker craft a malicious YAML config file with deeply nested structures or circular references that causes stack overflow or memory exhaustion when parsed by serde_yaml, leading to denial of service during governance proposal generation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: load_config()] [Path Traversal] Does the load_config() function properly validate the path parameter to prevent directory traversal attacks (e.g., '../../../etc/passwd'), allowing an attacker to read arbitrary files from the filesystem when loading configuration? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: parse()] [YAML Injection] Can an attacker inject malicious YAML anchors, aliases, or tags in the serialized config string that could lead to arbitrary object instantiation, memory exhaustion, or code execution when deserialized by serde_yaml? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: load_config()] [Resource Exhaustion] Does load_config() impose size limits on the input file to prevent an attacker from loading extremely large configuration files (e.g., multi-GB YAML) that could exhaust memory and crash the release builder process? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: parse()] [Unicode Exploitation] Can an attacker use unicode normalization attacks or homograph characters in config field names to bypass validation checks or inject malicious values that appear legitimate but behave differently when processed? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [URL Validation Bypass] In GasScheduleLocator::RemoteFile, can an attacker specify a malicious URL (e.g., 'file:///etc/passwd' or internal network addresses like '127.0.0.1:6379') to read local files or perform SSRF attacks against internal services? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [DNS Rebinding] When fetching remote gas schedules, can an attacker exploit DNS rebinding attacks where the domain initially resolves to a legitimate IP but later rebinds to an internal IP, allowing access to private network resources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Malicious Gas Schedule] Can an attacker host a malicious gas schedule JSON at a remote URL with crafted values (e.g., zero gas costs, integer overflows, or negative values) that bypass validation and get incorporated into governance proposals, breaking gas metering? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Man-in-the-Middle] Does fetch_gas_schedule() enforce HTTPS and validate TLS certificates when fetching remote gas schedules, or can an attacker perform MITM attacks to inject malicious gas configurations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Response Size Limit] Does the reqwest call impose size limits on the HTTP response to prevent an attacker from serving an extremely large JSON payload that exhausts memory during deserialization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Timeout Handling] Can an attacker cause the fetch_gas_schedule() async function to hang indefinitely by hosting a slow-responding server, leading to denial of service in proposal generation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Redirect Chain Exploitation] Can an attacker exploit HTTP redirect chains to bypass URL validation or cause excessive redirects that lead to resource exhaustion when fetching remote gas schedules? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: fetch_gas_schedule()] [Content-Type Validation] Does fetch_gas_schedule() validate the Content-Type header of the HTTP response to ensure it's application/json, or can an attacker serve non-JSON content that causes parsing errors or unexpected behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Struct: GasScheduleLocator] [Serialization Confusion] In the custom Serialize/Deserialize implementation, can an attacker craft ambiguous strings that could be interpreted as both local files and remote URLs, leading to unexpected file access patterns? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: GasScheduleLocator::deserialize()] [URL Parsing Bypass] Does the Url::parse() check properly validate all URL components (scheme, host, port), or can an attacker craft malicious URLs with empty hosts or invalid schemes that bypass security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: get_execution_hash()] [Hash Collision] Can an attacker craft two different Move scripts that produce the same execution hash, allowing them to substitute a malicious script after a proposal is approved but before execution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: get_execution_hash()] [Empty Result Handling] When result.is_empty() returns true and get_execution_hash() returns None, can an attacker exploit this to bypass hash validation in multi-step proposals, allowing execution without proper chaining? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: get_execution_hash()] [Temporary File Race Condition] Does the use of TempPath in get_execution_hash() create a race condition window where an attacker could modify the temporary file between creation and hash calculation, altering the execution hash? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: get_execution_hash()] [Unwrap Panic] The function uses .unwrap() multiple times without error handling - can an attacker craft inputs that cause these unwraps to panic, leading to denial of service in proposal generation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: append_script_hash()] [Hash Prefix Collision] Can an attacker manipulate the '// Script hash: {}' comment prefix to create scripts with identical hashes by exploiting how the hash is calculated, bypassing integrity checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: consolidated_side_effects()] [Feature Flag Squashing] When multiple FeatureFlag entries are squashed together, can an attacker exploit the squashing logic to hide malicious feature flag changes or create inconsistent state between proposal steps? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: generate_release_proposal_scripts()] [Reverse Iteration Attack] For MultiStep proposals, the update_sequence is processed in reverse and then reversed again - can this create ordering vulnerabilities where hash dependencies are incorrectly calculated? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: generate_release_script()] [Hash Chain Manipulation] In multi-step proposals where each step includes the hash of the next step, can an attacker break the hash chain by modifying intermediate proposals, causing execution failures or security bypasses? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: generate_release_script() - RawScript] [Template Injection] When using Handlebars to render Move templates with {{ script_hash }}, can an attacker inject malicious Handlebars expressions in the Move script that execute during template rendering, leading to code execution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/mod.rs] [Function: generate_release_script() - RawScript] [Path Traversal in Script Loading] Does the base_path.join(script_path) properly sanitize the script_path to prevent directory traversal attacks when loading raw Move scripts from the filesystem? (High)
